text:
This is all really great insight — thanks so much for taking the time to chime in <@UUXMCJQ15>, <@U024K88ECFN>, <@U0113AV4895>, and <@U026RJJ46UW>.

Here’s where I’m at:
We do require payment up front, but just for one month at a time. I think I need to start requiring a baseline of 3 months (then month to month after) instead of trying to make things super easy for the client by not locking them into _anything_. If I do that, it sets a better foundation to get them in the mindset of working together long-term. I like the idea of a consultation phase and tying everything we find back to a specific deliverable that the client could take and use whether they continue with us or not. If those things work in tandem (a “longer” term starting engagement vs whatever they want + some initial strategy work and deliverables), we’re doing a better job to set ourselves up for success over the long term and can include some margin for the admin stuff across a longer term/with initial strategy deliverables.

text:
<@U029CTQ5X6Y> Oh! Yes. Been there. In the first I always had to pitch my best ideas forwards and it used to contradicts with the other agency. Yes my ideas were good. But content is a debatable topic.

But as the campaign progresses, I have realized -  It is only better to showcase the quality through the work you do.

Once the company starts forming the trust in your agency and in your work - all things will work out on its own.

Tips -
1. Try to listen to other agencies
2. Stay minimal in the beginning and understand the company you are writing content for
3. Only ask the necessary questions in the beginning.
4. Do not oversell. 
5. Once the company starts trusting you - there will be no price cutdowns and competitions.

elements.text:
Oh! Yes. Been there. In the first I always had to pitch my best ideas forwards and it used to contradicts with the other agency. Yes my ideas were good. But content is a debatable topic.

But as the campaign progresses, I have realized -  It is only better to showcase the quality through the work you do.

Once the company starts forming the trust in your agency and in your work - all things will work out on its own.

Tips -
Try to listen to other agencies
Stay minimal in the beginning and understand the company you are writing content for
Only ask the necessary questions in the beginning.
Once the company starts trusting you - there will be no price cutdowns and competitions.

text:
Hey <@U014ZK7Q1TP> - I think there is a form - W-8BEN-E. It generally states that you are NOT a US business and don’t need to pay taxes for this country.

I am not entirely sure of the procedures. But at least you can check it out.

Hope that helps.
